Multimodal psychological profile and self-report changes:
Self-report instruments show a mixed pattern. Depressive symptoms as measured by the CES-D decreased markedly (22 → 6), shifting the participant from a higher symptom classification to a low-symptom profile, and trait anxiety (STAI) decreased slightly. Self-esteem declined modestly (40 → 37), and interpersonal trust fell marginally; self-reported happiness was unchanged and health satisfaction edged upward. These changes suggest an improvement in reported depressive symptom burden and modest reductions in trait anxiety, while self-evaluative and social-trust measures worsened slightly.

Sleep behavior and subjective sleep experience:
Objective and subjective sleep measures diverge in important ways. Median nightly sleep duration decreased by ~54 minutes (8h26m → 7h31m), and median sleep start time shifted substantially later (≈01:00 → ≈02:33), while night-to-night variability in both start time and duration decreased (more consistent but later and shorter sleep). Sleep latency increased markedly (20 → 60 minutes), indicating more difficulty initiating sleep despite slightly greater consistency in timing. The participant’s perceived control over sleep duration was unchanged. Overall, the sleep pattern has shifted later and shorter with increased time to fall asleep.

Wearable-derived physiology and circadian rhythm:
Heart-rate–based circadian measures indicate a loss of robust daily rhythmicity and a shift in timing. Interdaily stability and 24-hour autocorrelation both decreased substantially, amplitude of the circadian rhythm declined, and the acrophase shifted later (previous mid/late-afternoon peak → evening ~7:50 PM). Mesor increased slightly and resting heart rate rose (~76.4 → 77.9 bpm; elevated relative to the study sample), while aggregated hourly heart-rate profiles show relatively higher cardiac activity into the late evening and nocturnal hours compared with the previous wave. Together these changes reflect a delayed and blunted circadian pattern with higher baseline cardiovascular activation, particularly in the evening.

Behavioral activity and lifestyle:
Physical activity/exercise frequency declined to none from occasional activity. Sedentary leisure (internet use, music listening, sedentary hobby) increased, and the participant added regular video game time. Alcohol use increased slightly (beginning occasional wine/liquor). Socializing time was unchanged. The pattern is one of reduced physical activity and increased sedentary, screen-based behaviors.

Integrative interpretation with respect to perceived stress:
Physiological and behavioral indicators (increased sleep latency, later and shorter sleep, weakened interdaily stability and circadian amplitude, later acrophase, higher resting heart rate, and reduced exercise with greater sedentary time) collectively point toward increased physiological arousal and circadian disruption—patterns commonly associated with higher perceived stress. In contrast, self-report symptom measures show a large decline in depressive symptoms and a small reduction in trait anxiety, which would typically align with reduced perceived stress. The small declines in self-esteem and interpersonal trust may reflect social or self-evaluative strains that could increase perceived stress. Given the magnitude and coherence of objective physiological and behavioral deterioration (sleep initiation problems, circadian phase delay, elevated resting HR, loss of day-to-day rhythmicity, and markedly reduced exercise), these objective signals provide stronger directional information about acute stress-related physiological load than the single large improvement in depressive-symptom reporting. On balance, the multimodal evidence is more consistent with an increase in physiological and behavioral correlates of perceived stress despite improvement in depressive symptom scores.

Psychological self-report signals a marked worsening of affective state across waves. The CES-D increased dramatically (15 → 46), and STAI trait anxiety rose substantially (45 → 60), both changes large in magnitude and consistent with increased negative affect and anxiety proneness. Concurrently, trait self-esteem declined sharply (44 → 26) and a single-item happiness rating fell (4 → 1). Health satisfaction also decreased. Together these large, directionally-consistent changes in mood, anxiety, self-worth, and perceived health indicate a pronounced deterioration in subjective emotional functioning that would be expected to accompany higher perceived stress.

Behavioral and lifestyle indicators show mixed but mostly stress-consistent shifts. The participant reports markedly reduced alcohol use (from weekly use to none) and reduced socializing time; exercise patterns shifted toward more sport activity but less frequent solo and group exercise overall, while sedentary hobby time increased. Body mass index rose substantially (23.29 → 27.45). Reduced social engagement, increased sedentary time, and weight gain alongside fewer reported coping behaviors (less socializing) are behavioral patterns that commonly accompany greater perceived stress or distress, even though the cessation of alcohol use could be neutral or adaptive depending on context.

Sleep metrics indicate worsening sleep quality and greater irregularity. Self-reported sleep latency increased from ~30 to 100 minutes, and objective median nightly sleep decreased from ~7h49m to ~6h27m. Objective sleep start times shifted earlier by about 1h15m but became much more variable (sleep start SD increased markedly). Sleep duration variability also increased. This pattern — longer sleep latency, shorter median sleep on the device, and increased night-to-night variability — aligns with sleep disruption and fragmentation that typically co-occur with elevated stress and mood disturbance.

Wearable-derived physiological and circadian measures suggest increased tonic and daytime physiological activation and reduced day-to-day regularity. Resting heart rate and the cosinor mesor both increased (resting HR ~49 → 55.9 bpm; mesor +8.9), and daytime hourly heart-rate values show larger afternoon peaks in the current aggregated profile (notably very high values in the 2–4 pm window). Amplitude increased and acrophase shifted earlier, indicating a stronger but phase-advanced rhythm, while interdaily stability and 24-hour autocorrelation declined, signaling reduced regularity across days. Intradaily variability decreased (less fragmentation within days), but the overall pattern—higher baseline cardiac tone and larger daytime peaks together with less stable day-to-day rhythms—points to greater physiological arousal and disrupted circadian regularity, both consistent with elevated stress burden.

Integrative assessment and direction of change for perceived stress: multiple independent streams converge toward greater distress and physiological arousal. Large increases in depressive symptoms and trait anxiety, steep declines in self-esteem and happiness, objective signs of sleep disruption (longer latency, shorter median sleep, higher variability), increases in resting and daytime heart rate, and behavioral changes (less socializing, more sedentary time, weight gain) together form a coherent picture that aligns with an increase in perceived stress since the prior wave. Some isolated changes—reduced alcohol use and increased sport frequency—could be adaptive, but they do not outweigh the magnitude and consistency of worsening mood, sleep, and physiological arousal. On balance, the preponderance of evidence indicates the participant’s perceived stress has increased.

Self-report measures show small but consistent shifts in affective indicators. Scores on the CES-D and trait STAI both rose by a single point relative to the prior wave, although both remain at very low absolute levels and within the "not depressed"/"not anxious" range. Self-esteem fell modestly (−1 point) from an elevated baseline, while self-reported happiness remained high and unchanged. Interpersonal trust increased moderately. These patterns indicate minor deterioration on some negative affect and self-evaluation indices (small increases in depressive/anxious symptom scores and a small drop in self-esteem) coexisting with stable-to-improved social-affective indicators (unchanged high happiness and a rise in reported trust). Correlations linking these small score changes to PSS change are minimal in magnitude, so each shift should be interpreted as low-to-moderate evidence rather than strong proof of PSS change.

Lifestyle and activity behaviors present a mixed picture. The participant reports an increase in exercise frequency when exercising alone (from monthly to weekly) and consistently high frequency of exercising with others, indicating greater overall activity engagement. Substance use remains absent. Sedentary/leisure habits shifted modestly (less TV time, slightly more video game time). Academic performance and health satisfaction are unchanged, while BMI increased slightly (0.68). Increased physical activity would typically be expected to buffer perceived stress, whereas the small BMI increase and modest changes in leisure patterns are unlikely to drive large shifts in stress on their own.

Sleep data show divergent signals between quantity and regularity. Median nightly sleep duration increased from about 6h11m to 6h47m (a moderate gain), and subjective weekday sleep duration rose by 30 minutes. However, measures of sleep consistency show marked deterioration: standard deviation of sleep duration rose substantially (from 105 to 138 minutes) and sleep start time variability more than doubled (SD increase of ~72 minutes). Sleep latency increased slightly (5 to 10 minutes). Increased total sleep time alongside substantially greater night-to-night variability and more irregular sleep timing suggests improved quantity but worse regularity; sleep irregularity is independently associated with poorer stress regulation and may be more consequential for perceived stress than the modest increase in average duration.

Wearable-derived circadian and cardiovascular metrics corroborate a decrease in rhythm regularity alongside mixed changes in basal physiology. Interdaily stability declined (0.53 → 0.42) while intradaily variability rose slightly, and 24-hour autocorrelation fell — all indicating that day-to-day structure in heart-rate patterns weakened. MESOR (mean circadian heart-rate) decreased slightly while amplitude increased; resting heart rate rose by 0.9 bpm but remains low in absolute terms (48.5 bpm, well below population mean). Hourly aggregated heart-rate profiles show lower values at many daytime hours compared with the prior wave, but there are some shifts in midday peaks. Overall, the circadian heart-rate profile is less stable and more fragmented than previously, a pattern that is plausibly linked to greater physiological stress vulnerability even though mean heart-rate indices remain within a fit range. Correlations of these wearable deltas with PSS change are small, so these signals provide modest evidence toward change in perceived stress rather than definitive proof.

Holistic synthesis and directional assessment: the multimodal data present competing influences. Protective signals include increased exercise frequency, a modest increase in total sleep duration, stable high happiness and increased interpersonal trust, and low absolute levels of depressive and anxiety symptoms. Adverse signals include marked increases in sleep timing and duration variability, decreased interdaily stability and increased intradaily variability in heart-rate circadian metrics, small rises in depressive/anxiety scores and a small drop in self-esteem, and a small BMI increase. The participant’s initial PSS was below average, and the dataset reports a negative correlation between initial PSS and subsequent change (higher initial PSS linked to later decreases), which statistically implies participants with a relatively low initial PSS (as here) are more likely to show increases. Taken together, the balance of evidence — particularly the substantial worsening of sleep regularity and circadian stability alongside small adverse shifts in affective self-report — points toward a modest increase in perceived stress relative to the prior wave. Uncertainty remains because several salutary changes (exercise, greater sleep quantity, stable happiness) countervail this trend, but overall the pattern supports a net increase in perceived stress.

Paragraph 1 — Self-report psychological measures and mood: The strongest signals in the survey data indicate improvement in internalizing symptoms between waves. The CES-D score fell markedly from 15 to 5 (delta -10), and the STAI–Trait score declined from 50 to 41 (delta -9); both changes are sizable and point to reductions in depressive symptoms and trait anxiety. Health satisfaction rose (3.44 → 4.33), and self-reported happiness was unchanged. Self-esteem decreased modestly (42 → 38), and interpersonal trust declined (2.83 → 2.33). The direction and magnitude of the CES-D and STAI changes are the most salient psychological signals and, given their positive correlations with PSS change in the dataset, would be expected to accompany a reduction in perceived stress. The modest drop in self-esteem and the larger drop in trust are countervailing influences but are smaller in magnitude than the improvements on depression/anxiety indices.

Paragraph 2 — Behavior and lifestyle changes: Daily activities shifted in mixed ways. The participant increased time on video games substantially and reduced internet browsing time; socializing and reading both increased modestly. Exercise with others decreased by one frequency unit (e.g., from ≥3×/week to 1–2×/week) and exercising alone remained nil. Alcohol use patterns were stable. In aggregate, social engagement and recreational reading increased (generally protective for well-being), while organized/partnered exercise decreased and gaming increased (potentially compensatory or avoidance-oriented). These behavioral shifts are mixed but lean toward improved social and leisure engagement despite reduced group exercise.

Paragraph 3 — Subjective and wearable sleep: Sleep shows modest improvement and greater regularity. Self-reported normal weekday sleep duration increased by about one hour and median Fitbit sleep duration rose by ~14 minutes (to a median 7 h 46 min). Night-to-night variability decreased substantially (sleep duration SD down from 82 to 54 minutes), and sleep start times shifted later (median start ~1:15 AM → 2:06 AM) while becoming more consistent (start time SD decreased by ~55 minutes). Sleep latency doubled from 10 to 20 minutes but remains within a commonly acceptable range. Overall the pattern is increased total sleep and greater consistency, which typically aligns with reduced perceived stress and better recovery.

Paragraph 4 — Circadian and cardiovascular physiology: Circadian rhythm summaries show a modest reorganization: MESOR (average heart rate) increased slightly (+2.5), amplitude of the 24-hour rhythm decreased (-2.37), and acrophase shifted later by roughly an hour, consistent with the later habitual sleep times. Interdaily stability fell minimally while autocorrelation at 24 hours increased, indicating mixed changes in day-to-day rhythm regularity with a slightly stronger 24-hour autocorrelation but lower overall stability. Resting heart rate increased by ~1.9 bpm. Hourly mean heart rates are elevated across many daytime/evening hours compared with the prior period, producing a modest upward shift in cardiovascular tone. These physiological changes (small RHR increase, lower amplitude) could reflect greater sympathetic tone or lifestyle shifts (later schedule, changed activity patterns); their magnitudes are moderate and not as large as the psychological improvements observed.

Paragraph 5 — Integrated interpretation and implications for perceived stress (PSS): The largest and most consistent signals favor reduced perceived stress: large decreases in depressive symptoms and trait anxiety, increased health satisfaction, longer and more regular sleep, and increased social/leisure engagement. The initial PSS was relatively elevated (24.0) and the dataset reports a negative correlation between initial PSS and subsequent change, which is consistent with larger improvements among those starting higher. Countervailing signals include a small rise in resting heart rate and MESOR, reduced circadian amplitude, loss of interpersonal trust, decreased group exercise, and increased gaming; these suggest some physiological arousal and shifts in coping/behavior that could attenuate improvement for some stress domains. On balance, the magnitude and direction of the psychological symptom improvements (CES-D, STAI) together with sleep stabilization and higher health satisfaction provide stronger evidence for a net decrease in perceived stress than for an increase.

Psychological self-report measures show several notable changes that point toward reduced affective symptom burden. The CES-D score fell by 4 points (16 → 12), moving the participant from the “depressed” classification to “not depressed,” and the STAI–Trait score declined by 4 points (49 → 45) though it remains elevated relative to the sample mean. Self-reported happiness and interpersonal trust both increased modestly. These mood- and anxiety-related changes have positive delta correlations with PSS change (CES-D Δ correlation = 0.26; STAI Δ correlation = 0.19), meaning the observed reductions in depressive and anxiety symptoms are the kind of changes that tend to accompany reductions in perceived stress. Counterbalancing these improvements is a large drop in global self-esteem (Rosenberg score decreased by 9 points), which is a substantive negative shift in self-appraisal that could act to maintain or raise perceived stress; however, the correlation of self-esteem change with PSS change is small in magnitude.

Behavioral and lifestyle data present a mixed pattern. The participant reports substantially less exercise (both alone and with others declined from roughly weekly to less than monthly), increased time spent on internet use, and greater engagement in a sedentary hobby; socializing time remained stable. Self-reported sleep also worsened subjectively: sleep latency increased by 20 minutes and reported normal weekday sleep decreased by one hour. By contrast, objective wearable sleep metrics show a modest increase in median sleep duration (+23 minutes) but increased night-to-night variability and a later median sleep start time (~30 minutes later). The subjective worsening of sleep latency and decreased weekday sleep duration has a small negative delta correlation with PSS change (i.e., these changes are of the type that could be associated with increased stress), whereas the small objective increase in median sleep duration has negligible correlation with PSS change. Overall, the reduction in physical activity and increase in sleep timing variability are potential contributors to sustained or increased stress, but several of these changes have weak correlations with PSS change.

Wearable-derived physiological and circadian metrics suggest altered daily organization with modest signs of greater fragmentation but lower daytime cardiovascular peaks. Circadian parametrics show a slight reduction in MESOR and a small increase in amplitude; non-parametric metrics indicate a small drop in interdaily stability and an increase in intradaily variability (IV), the latter reflecting more fragmented within-day rhythmicity. Resting heart rate remains elevated relative to the study population but decreased slightly from the prior wave; aggregated hourly heart-rate profiles show lower peak values in several daytime hours compared with the previous period. The increase in intradaily variability is positively correlated with PSS change (IV Δ correlation = 0.10), so greater fragmentation would be expected to associate with increased perceived stress, whereas the modest reductions in some daytime heart-rate peaks and in resting HR align with decreased physiological arousal and could correspond with lower perceived stress. These physiological signals are mixed but small in magnitude.

Synthesizing across modalities, affective self-report improvements (notably decreased depressive symptoms and reduced trait anxiety, plus increased happiness and trust) constitute the strongest and most consistent signal pointing toward reduced perceived stress. Several behavioral and physiological indices provide countervailing evidence (large decline in self-esteem, marked reduction in exercise, increased circadian fragmentation, and subjective reports of worse sleep latency and less weekday sleep), but the effect sizes and the delta–PSS correlations for these countervailing measures are generally smaller or mixed. Given the pattern of sizable mood/anxiety improvements that are positively associated with PSS change and the relatively weaker, mixed signals from lifestyle and physiological data, the overall balance of evidence indicates that the participant’s perceived stress is more likely to have decreased or remained stable rather than worsened.

Summary of multimodal change:
Across self-report and wearable domains the participant shows a mixed pattern of behavioral and physiological change, with several signals pointing toward worsening perceived well-being alongside a few indicators of improved physiological regulation. Subjective mood and self-concept measures shifted notably in a negative direction: self-reported happiness decreased by 2 points (from 5 to 3, a large relative drop, Z-score of the change ≈ -1.8) and self‑esteem declined by 4 points (Z-change ≈ -0.72). Trait anxiety rose slightly (STAI +2 points), while depressive symptom score (CES‑D) remained stable at 17. Daily social engagement decreased modestly (socializing −1 hour), while solitary leisure (listening to music) increased (+2 hours). Alcohol use (beer) increased in frequency from monthly to weekly. These subjective and behavioral shifts—especially the large decreases in happiness and self-esteem and reduced social time—are commonly associated with increased perceived stress or a worsening subjective stress profile.

Wearable-derived sleep and circadian patterns:
Fitbit-derived sleep shows only a small reduction in median nightly sleep duration (≈8 minutes shorter) but a meaningful delay and destabilization of sleep timing: median sleep start shifted later by ~31 minutes and night‑to‑night start-time variability increased by about 30 minutes. Circadian rhythm metrics indicate reduced regularity: interdaily stability decreased (−0.07) and autocorrelation at 24 hours declined, while intradaily variability increased slightly. The cosinor acrophase shifted about one hour later (5:09 PM → 6:09 PM), consistent with a phase delay. Taken together, these wearable findings indicate a modest decline in the stability and timing of daily physiological rhythms, which is often linked to greater perceived stress and poorer mood even when total sleep time changes little.

Cardiovascular / physiological signals:
Resting heart rate decreased by ~2.7 bpm (61.6 → 58.9), a change that by itself typically reflects improved cardiovascular recovery or fitness and could indicate reduced tonic sympathetic arousal. Hourly aggregated heart-rate profiles show a relative lowering in some daytime hours but higher mean heart rates in late evening hours (notably an increase around 8–11 PM compared with the prior period). The amplitude and mesor of the circadian fit are essentially stable. Thus physiological arousal signals are mixed: a lower resting heart rate suggests reduced baseline physiological strain, while the later-evening elevations and reduced circadian regularity point toward increased evening arousal and circadian disruption.

Behavioral activity and lifestyle:
The participant reports modest increases in physical activity participation (exercising alone/with others and sports increased from near-zero to low but positive frequencies), which could support stress resilience. However, socializing decreased and substance use (beer) increased in frequency. Sedentary recreational patterns remain relatively high (TV, video games), although time on video games decreased slightly. Health satisfaction rose modestly. Overall, lifestyle changes are heterogeneous: some health-promoting behaviors increased (exercise, lower resting HR), while social engagement fell and alcohol use rose.

Integration and inference about perceived stress direction:
Weighing the evidence, the strongest and most salient indicators of worsening subjective state are the large declines in happiness and self-esteem, and reduced social engagement—changes that are closely tied to perceived stress and emotional burden. Circadian destabilization and later sleep timing further support the interpretation of increased psychosocial strain, particularly because these changes were more pronounced than the very small drop in sleep duration. Countervailing evidence includes a reduced resting heart rate and small increases in exercise frequency and health satisfaction, which could reflect improved physiological fitness or compensatory health behaviors. However, these physiological/behavioral improvements appear smaller in magnitude and less directly tied to subjective distress than the pronounced negative shifts in mood and self-concept. On balance, the multimodal pattern (marked decreases in happiness and self-esteem, increased evening arousal and circadian irregularity, reduced social time, and increased alcohol frequency) is more consistent with an overall increase in perceived stress since the prior wave.

Paragraph 1 — Self-report psychological and affective change:
Relative to the prior wave, self-reported affect and trait measures show a mixed pattern. Trait anxiety (STAI) is slightly lower (44 → 42), and self-esteem is unchanged, while depressive symptoms on the CES-D rose modestly (8 → 11) but remain below clinical thresholds. General happiness and interpersonal trust are unchanged at relatively lower-than-average levels. Notable positive change is a marked increase in self-rated health satisfaction (2.78 → 4.33), and BMI declined (28.69 → 26.21), which may reflect improvements in perceived physical health. Taken together, subjective psychological indicators do not show a clear large shift in one direction: anxiety edged down slightly, depressive symptoms increased modestly, and global satisfaction with health improved substantially.

Paragraph 2 — Behavioral and lifestyle changes:
Behavioral habits are likewise mixed. Daily recreation patterns and heavy internet use remain unchanged and above the population mean (internet >4 hours). Socializing time is stable. Exercise done alone decreased in frequency, while exercising with others remained stable and participation in sports increased from none to occasional — a small net increase in structured physical activity but less solitary exercise. Alcohol use shows a small increase in wine/liquor frequency. The participant also reports less perceived control over sleep duration (from “Agree” to “Somewhat agree”), and their ideal weekday sleep declined (desire shortened from 8 to 7 hours), even though reported weekday sleep duration remained steady at about 6 hours. These behavioral shifts suggest some changes in routines (less solitary exercise, persistent high internet use, lower subjective sleep control) that could influence stress regulation.

Paragraph 3 — Sleep/wearable sleep metrics:
Objective sleep from the wearable is largely stable. Median nightly sleep duration is essentially unchanged and near 6 hours 54 minutes, sleep timing moved earlier by about 28 minutes, and night-to-night variability in duration and start time decreased slightly. These patterns indicate modest gains in regularity and an earlier median sleep onset, but absolute sleep duration remains short relative to typical recommendations and the participant reports reduced control over sleep length. Stability and slightly earlier timing could be protective for stress, whereas persistently short sleep opportunity may limit recovery.

Paragraph 4 — Circadian and cardiovascular physiology:
Wearable-derived circadian features indicate more pronounced baseline cardiovascular activation. The MESOR (mean circadian heart rate) increased by ~4.9 bpm and resting heart rate rose by ~2.1 bpm; amplitude also increased modestly. Interdaily stability remained high and intradaily variability decreased (less within-day fragmentation), suggesting a more regular day-to-day rhythm but at a higher baseline heart-rate set point. Hourly aggregated heart rates show elevated daytime and evening values compared with the prior wave (notably mid-day and late-afternoon/evening hours), consistent with increased tonic physiological arousal across the day. This combination — greater regularity but a higher mean heart rate and elevated hourly rates — is most consistent with increased basal cardiovascular activation rather than improved autonomic downregulation.

Paragraph 5 — Integrative interpretation with respect to perceived stress:
Evidence for an increase in perceived stress: (a) objective physiology shows higher resting and mean heart rate and elevated hourly heart rates, which are reliable markers of increased sympathetic tone or sustained physiological load; (b) small rise in depressive symptom score and reduced perceived control over sleep could reflect greater subjective strain; and (c) reduced frequency of solitary exercise and persistent high internet time may reduce coping resources. Evidence for stability or improvement: (a) trait anxiety decreased slightly and self-rated health satisfaction improved substantially, and (b) sleep timing regularity improved and sleep variability decreased. Weighing these streams, the physiological indicators of increased tonic arousal (MESOR, resting HR, daytime HR elevations) are robust and often closely related to stress burden, and they are coupled with small adverse shifts in mood and perceived sleep control despite gains in health satisfaction. On balance the multimodal signal points to a modest worsening in stress-related physiological load with some compensatory subjective improvements; overall, the balance favors a small increase in perceived stress relative to the prior wave.

Multimodal summary and context
Across the two measurement waves the participant’s profile shows a mixture of favorable changes in mood, sleep regulation, and physiology alongside a few indicators of potential risk (reduced self-reported happiness and increased alcohol use). Objective wearable data indicate a lower cardiovascular set point (lower MESOR and lower resting heart rate) and tighter sleep timing regularity; self-reported measures show reductions in depressive symptoms and trait anxiety and small gains in self-esteem and perceived control over sleep. Taken together, these multimodal signals point more toward improved physiological regulation and some aspects of emotional functioning than toward a clear worsening of perceived stress, although not every indicator is uniformly positive.

Self-report psychological measures
On standardized self-report instruments the participant’s CES-D score fell (6 → 4) and STAI–Trait decreased (44 → 41), both shifts consistent with reduced depressive symptom burden and lower trait anxiety since the prior wave. Rosenberg self-esteem increased modestly (33 → 35), and trust and health satisfaction increased slightly. One countervailing self-report is the single-item happiness rating, which declined (4 → 3); this decrease may capture a change in momentary well-being not reflected in the trait measures. Overall, the dominant pattern in the validated trait scales is toward modest improvement in affective symptoms and self-regard, which—based on the reported delta correlations for STAI and CES-D—would be expected to accompany stable or lower perceived stress.

Sleep and circadian/physiological patterns
Objective sleep and circadian metrics show improved regularity and largely preserved quantity. Median nightly sleep length decreased slightly (~22 minutes) but remains relatively long (~8 h 6 m), and night-to-night variability in sleep start time decreased substantially (start-time SD reduced from 82 to 48 minutes). The participant also reports shorter sleep latency (15 → 10 minutes) and a subjective increase in perceived control over sleep duration (from “Disagree” to “Somewhat Agree”), supporting better perceived sleep quality and routine. Heart-rate–derived circadian measures show a notable drop in MESOR (≈ -6.2 bpm) and a decline in resting heart rate (≈ -5.4 bpm), with amplitude essentially unchanged; these changes are consistent with a lower baseline cardiovascular activation across the recording period. Nonparametric rhythm measures (interdaily stability, intradaily variability, autocorrelation at 24 h) show small declines but little directional change overall. The aggregate pattern—improved sleep regularity and lower resting HR/MESOR—better aligns with reduced physiological stress or improved fitness/recovery rather than heightened chronic stress.

Activity, substance use, and daily routines
The participant reports continued high engagement in physical activity (sports and exercise with others remain frequent) and increased frequency of exercising alone; greater exercise consistency is typically associated with improved mood and lower perceived stress. Recreational drug use remains absent; however, alcohol use increased from “not at all” to “1–2 times a week” for beer and modestly for wine. The beer-use change is a relatively large delta relative to the sample (large Z-Score of the change), although its reported delta correlation with PSS change is very small. Leisure patterns (limited TV/internet/video game use) are essentially unchanged. Taken together, the behavioral profile largely supports maintenance or improvement of stress-buffering behaviors (exercise, stable routines), with a notable increase in alcohol frequency that warrants monitoring but is not strongly tied by the provided correlations to worsening PSS in this dataset.

Evidence for worsening perceived stress
The clearest signals that could reflect increased perceived stress are the drop in single-item happiness and the increase in alcohol consumption; the happiness decrease had a modest negative delta correlation (suggesting changes in happiness relate to PSS change) and may indicate some decline in momentary well-being. Circadian nonparametric measures show slight declines in interdaily stability and autocorrelation which, on their own, could be interpreted as small reductions in day-to-day regularity (a potential stress-related pattern), but these changes are small in magnitude.

Evidence for improvement or stability in perceived stress
Stronger evidence points toward stability or improvement: reductions in CES-D and STAI scores, increases in self-esteem and perceived control over sleep, improved sleep-timing regularity, and a lower resting heart rate/MESOR are all consistent with reduced physiological arousal and improved affective functioning. Many of these measures have delta correlations that, when combined with their observed direction of change (e.g., anxiety and depressive symptom reductions), predict decreases in PSS or maintenance of lower stress. High and stable engagement in physical activity and improved sleep regularity are additional supportive factors for stable or lower perceived stress.

Holistic assessment and conclusion
Weighing the constellation of changes, the preponderance of evidence supports either stable or decreased perceived stress compared with the prior wave. Improvements in validated trait mood measures (CES-D, STAI), gains in self-esteem and sleep control, more regular sleep timing, and reductions in resting heart rate and MESOR are relatively robust and coherent indicators of reduced physiological and psychological strain. The principal adverse signals are a drop in a single-item happiness score and an increase in alcohol frequency; these are important to monitor but do not outweigh the multiple convergent markers of improvement. On balance, the data indicate that perceived stress has remained stable or declined since the previous assessment.

Summary of self-report psychological measures: Across survey waves the participant shows concurrent, substantive increases in symptom-report measures of negative affect alongside declines in protective self-appraisals. Depressive symptoms (CES-D) rose from 20 to 27 (Δ = +7), and trait anxiety (STAI) increased from 48 to 56 (Δ = +8). Self-esteem declined by 6 points (33 → 27). These changes are moderate-to-large in magnitude relative to the study population (notable positive Z-score shifts for CES-D and STAI; negative Z-score shift for self-esteem). Health satisfaction and interpersonal trust also decreased from previously higher values. The direction and size of these survey changes are commonly associated with increased subjective stress in the broader literature; the provided delta correlations for CES-D (0.25) and STAI (0.19) with PSS change are positive, supporting their relevance to increases in perceived stress, though these correlations are modest.

Behavioral and lifestyle changes: The participant reports increases in social activity (socializing time up by one category), sedentary hobby time (a large increase), reading and music-listening, and a modest initiation or increase in alcohol use (beer and wine moved from “not at all” to “1–2 times a month”). Exercise frequency largely held steady for solo exercise but the frequency of organized sports decreased by one category. The pattern suggests some increased social and leisure engagement but also greater sedentary recreation and small increases in alcohol use. These behavioral shifts are mixed in their likely effects on stress: increased socialization and leisure reading could be protective, whereas reduced sports frequency, increased sedentary time, and initiation of alcohol use are more consistent with coping responses to elevated stress or mood symptoms.

Sleep and circadian/physiological markers: Median nightly sleep duration increased modestly (≈18 minutes; from ~6h9m to ~6h27m) but remains below the participant’s stated ideal of 7 hours; subjective control over sleep duration is unchanged and rated low. Sleep timing became slightly earlier and more regular (median start ~12 minutes earlier; start-time SD decreased from 77 to 53 minutes), while night-to-night variability in sleep duration increased slightly. Wearable-derived circadian metrics indicate reduced circadian amplitude (14.34 → 12.09) and a small decrease in mesor, together with increased intradaily variability (0.28 → 0.40) and a slight decline in interdaily stability. Resting heart rate rose modestly (54.0 → 55.3 bpm). Aggregated hourly heart-rate profiles show attenuation of the previous daytime–evening peaks (reduced amplitude) and modest upward shifts in some afternoon/evening hours. Collectively these wearable signals point to a weakening and fragmentation of daily physiological rhythms and a small increase in baseline physiological arousal—patterns that are often observed in association with elevated perceived stress and mood symptom burden.

Integrated interpretation and weighing of evidence: The strongest, most consistent indicators across modalities point toward an increase in psychological distress and perceived stress. Large increases in depressive and anxiety symptom scores and the decline in self-esteem constitute direct, self-reported markers of worsening affective state. Circadian and autonomic measures (reduced amplitude, greater intradaily variability, slightly higher resting HR) provide objective, convergent evidence of greater physiological dysregulation and rhythm fragmentation. Behavioral markers are mixed but include potentially maladaptive changes (more sedentary recreation, reduced sports participation, modest uptake of alcohol use) that align with stress-related coping. A few signals (slightly longer median sleep and increased socializing/happiness rating) are temporally discordant and may reflect partial compensatory behaviors, but they do not offset the consistent pattern of worsening mood/anxiety symptoms and weakened physiological rhythms. Given the magnitude and consistency of the symptom increases and the objective circadian/physiological changes that typically accompany elevated stress, the preponderance of evidence supports an increase in perceived stress relative to the prior wave.
